item.title: Beogram 4000: Alternate "Circuit Diagram 2" with 24V Scale Illumination Lamps
item.description: I recently acquired a well-preserved Beogram 4000 service manual containing a unique supplementary diagram. This diagram, Circuit Diagram 2, outlines the control system and features a notable difference in the position scale illumination. Instead of the typical two 12V bulbs wired in series, it depicts two 24V bulbs connected in parallel to the 24V power source. This discovery complicated a recent interaction with Sonavor, who is currently restoring his own Beogram 4000.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description: Replacing the original DIN or RCA plugs is a crucial step when restoring a Beogram 4002. The old plugs often show corrosion due to the lack of gold plating. Upgrading to modern, all-metal plugs with gold-plated terminals is recommended. This upgrade minimizes electromagnetic interference and ensures optimal signal transfer to the amplifier by maintaining low contact resistance, especially important for the delicate MMC20 cartridge signals. The original RCA plugs on a Beogram 4002 (5513) being restored were in poor condition.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a Neutrik Gold Plated DIN5 Plug
item.description: A common improvement for the Beogram 4000 is replacing the DIN5 plug with a gold-plated version. The older plugs, often corroded, benefit from the upgrade. This particular Beogram 4000 was no exception. Here’s a comparison of the old plug and the new, gleaming Neutrik plug (Newark 27B4483): The old plug was removed, and the cable was prepped for the new plug. Stripping the outer insulation to this length works well:

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival From Massachusetts - First Look
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable arrived from a Massachusetts customer for a complete restoration. Thankfully, it was properly packaged and arrived without damage. The turntable’s dust cover shows typical signs of use, but it will be replaced with a new one. The aluminum surfaces are in good shape overall. However, there are some minor flaws. The keypad has a corner ding, suggesting it might have come loose during past transportation. Additionally, there are small scratches on the aluminum, possibly from the keypad moving around.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cleaning of the Tone Arm Carriage Position Switches and a Non-Returning Carriage
item.description: As a preliminary step in the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, I chose to verify the functionality of its control system. Prior testing had shown that the arm carriage would not return to its home position when moved across the platter without a record in place. Instead, it would travel to the center of the platter and stop. Ideally, the carriage should trigger the End Switch (ES) at this point and subsequently return to its home position on the right, turning off the turntable.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description: Over time, many Beogram devices have developed corroded DIN or RCA plugs. It’s a good idea to replace these old connectors with new, gold-plated ones. This specific Beogram 4002 (5513) came with RCA connectors. I typically use large, modern, high-quality metal plugs for replacements. However, this project had a unique requirement: the Beogram needed to connect to a Beolab 5000. The Beolab 5000 has a compact compartment for its connectors, which creates limitations on plug size.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Arm Lowering Mechanism, Replacement of Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with a LED Assembly, and a New Aluminum Pulley
item.description: My Beogram 4000 arrived damaged from shipping, so I began by fixing it. The carriage, which moves along a rod with bearings, had detached. I took out the rod and bearings to put them back into the carriage correctly. Then, I used a wrench to secure them. This allowed me to reinstall the carriage. Next, I started my usual restoration process, beginning with the arm lowering mechanism. I took apart the solenoid, damper, connecting parts, and springs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoring the Hood
item.description: Restoring a Beogram often includes restoring its hood, as many have accumulated scratches over time. This particular Beogram 4002 (5513) had deep scratches on its hood. The restoration started by sanding with 220-grit sandpaper, then progressively moved to finer grits (320-grit shown). This process, which took about 3 hours and involved around 10 polishing steps with Micro-Mesh up to 12000 level, returned the hood to a translucent and shiny condition.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Main and Power Supply PCBs
item.description: Following the replacement of the reservoir and motor capacitors on the Beogram 4000, the next stage was to focus on the main and power supply PCBs. It’s recommended to replace the RPM relay and trimmers alongside the electrolytic capacitors due to their susceptibility to corrosion. The main PCB in its original state can be seen here: A closer look at the outdated Siemens relay and RPM trimmers: And the outcome after component replacement:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Gold Plated DIN Plug
item.description: During the ongoing refurbishment of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, a corroded DIN5 plug was replaced after a new output relay had been installed. The original plug showed significant signs of wear. A high-quality Rean DIN5 plug with gold-plated terminals was chosen as a replacement. Photos document the preparation of the cable and the installation process. The author notes the limited space inside the DIN5 plug, making it difficult to separate the signal and ground connections.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from Germany En Route to California
item.description: I recently acquired a Beogram 4000 turntable from Germany, intended for a customer in California. My task is to refurbish the unit and deliver it to its new owner. The turntable was poorly packaged for shipment, resulting in the keypad plates becoming detached during transit. This led to minor damage to the plates themselves and some cosmetic imperfections on other internal surfaces. The aluminum surfaces are in surprisingly good shape considering the loose keypad plates.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Restoration and Test Drive with Cal Tjader and Claus Ogerman
item.description: I recently began restoring a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable for an Australian customer who purchased it on eBay. The turntable arrived in poor condition. My initial evaluation is documented here. This post details the unit’s restoration, excluding the dust cover, which will be covered separately. I began with the DC platter motor, as is customary, since the bearing lubrication process requires a few days. Here’s the motor after removal:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Replacing the Original DIN5 Plug with a Modern All-Metal Gold Plated Unit
item.description: To fully restore a 4002, replacing the often corroded DIN5 connector is essential. The delicate low-voltage signals need optimal contact. Gold is an ideal material due to its resistance to oxidation, ensuring a strong and long-lasting connection. The pictures illustrate this process, showing the old connector’s condition, preparing the cable for the new connector, the soldering process, and finally, the pristine new gold-plated connector installed. This upgrade is a significant step towards bringing the Beogram back to its former glory.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Non-Working End Groove Detection - Repair of a Detached Carriage Position Sensor
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration is nearly complete. One peculiar problem was a detached carriage position sensor, which is housed within a black light shield. This shield was hanging at an angle, but it needs to be positioned vertically. The sensor works by using black sections on a plexiglass strip attached to the carriage to interrupt light from an IR diode. If the sensor is misaligned, stray light can disrupt the carriage’s movement.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival and a First Look
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable from Norway recently arrived for restoration. The packaging was excellent, using the original styrofoam inserts, and the only issue was two loose control pads, which were prevented from causing damage due to tape and foam inside. This highlights the importance of securing these pads with non-residue tape during shipping. Fortunately, this is an easy repair. Cosmetically, the Beogram is in excellent condition. The aluminum panels will gleam like new with a thorough cleaning.

item.title: Beogram 4000 Arrives From UK! Solenoid Oscillates!
item.description: I recently acquired another Beogram 4000 from the UK. The unit is in fair shape; importantly, the MMC cartridge mount is undamaged and the sensor arm insert is present. The control panel for the cueing and tonearm lift detached during shipping, highlighting the wisdom of securing such parts. Thankfully, the seller had protected the turntable with a durable plastic sheet, preventing any damage. Reattaching the panel should be simple. Internally, all parts appear to be present:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Gap at the Carriage Servo Pulley Bearing
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, significant longitudinal play was discovered in the threaded rod responsible for moving the carriage. This play resulted in a ‘clacking’ noise whenever the carriage changed direction. The issue was resolved by removing the servo pulley, damaged locking ring, and worn plastic washer. A new, thick 2-56 nylon washer, which fit snugly on the shaft, replaced the locking ring and washer. The locking ring became unnecessary as the pulley was secured with a setscrew.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Completing the Restoration and a Test Spin with Weather Report!
item.description: This Beogram 4000 restoration project is complete, and it’s time to review the work. Two previous posts covered specific repairs: addressing a missing transistor insulator and a faulty motor driver transistor, and creating a 3D printed replacement for the fragile MMC cartridge mounts. This post summarizes the remaining restoration work. Typically, the process begins with a complete overhaul of the turntable’s carriage. This involves disassembling and cleaning all moving parts, such as the arm lowering mechanism.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing a Broken MMC Cartridge Mount with a 3D Printed Replacement Assembly
item.description: The first issue to tackle on this Beogram 4000 restoration was a damaged cartridge mount, a common problem on these turntables. The existing mount had a broken plastic piece. This particular unit came with both a damaged 4002 arm and its original, detached 4000 arm. The goal was to remove the 4002 arm and install the original arm after fitting it with a functional MMC mount. This project provided a perfect opportunity to use a recently designed 3D-printed replacement MMC mount.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Platter, Cleaning the Panels and Installing a 3D Printed Guiding Washer for the Cabinet
item.description: I dedicated some time today to refining the appearance of the Beogram 4000 I’m currently working on. The first step involved adjusting the platter’s height and alignment within the aluminum panel. Achieving a centered and flush platter is crucial for the Beogram’s visual appeal. The platter was positioned too low upon arrival, even grazing the panel due to misalignment. Therefore, I made adjustments to the main bearing and the chassis’s three suspension points to achieve the correct setup.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of Hood Mounting Screw Springs
item.description: During my quest for the ideal Beogram 4000 turntable, I’ve observed that none of the early models possess the hood mounting screw springs found on the later Beogram 4002 and 4004. These springs make removing and attaching the hood significantly easier. After consulting the service manuals, it’s clear that the Beogram 4000 was not designed with these springs. It seems B&O employed a continuous improvement approach, refining their designs over time.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Installation of a New DIN5 Plug With Gold Coated Terminals
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5514) restoration is coming along nicely. I believe a key part of revitalizing these turntables is installing a new, all-metal DIN 5 plug with gold-plated contacts. The old plugs often suffer from corrosion, which hinders the delicate signal transfer from the MMC cartridge. For example, here’s a picture of the old plug with tarnished terminals: This image showcases the soldering work within the updated plug: And finally, the finished product:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Reservoir and Motor Capacitors Using a 3D Printed Adapter
item.description: I’m working on restoring a Beogram 4000 turntable, and one of the challenges is finding modern replacements for the large capacitors used in the 1970s. I received a 3D-printed adapter that allows me to neatly install smaller, current-generation capacitors. These photos show the adapter with the new capacitors in place: For reliability, I used two 300uF capacitors wired together to replace the original 150uF motor capacitor. The remaining capacitors are high-quality Rubycon, Panasonic, and Multicomp components chosen for their longevity.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A Strange Solenoid and an Alien 7812 Impostor
item.description: As I was testing the restored tonearm carriage on my Beogram 8000 with some recently purchased Genesis reissues (Trespass, Foxtrot, Nursery Crime, etc.), I decided to turn my attention to the Beogram 4000 I had recently acquired from Italy. The most critical issue was its malfunctioning solenoid, which appeared unusual and unlike standard B&O components. Upon disassembling the damper/solenoid assembly, I discovered a makeshift repair job. The original solenoid had been replaced with a different one, and a nail was used as a plunger to activate the solenoid linkage.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adding a Grounding Switch
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, a significant hum became apparent when connected to a Beomaster 6000 amplifier. This was unexpected, as a Beogram 4002 with the same grounding design showed no such issue. The only identifiable difference between the two models was the unshielded mains transformer in the 4000, unlike the shielded transformers in later models. While the relevance of this difference was unclear, it appeared to be the only variable.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): Full Functional Restoration and Installation of Beolover Commander Remote
item.description: This article details the restoration process of a Beogram 4002 turntable from Texas, following an initial assessment. The author mentions a slight delay due to relocating to Albuquerque. The turntable was mostly original, suggesting a straightforward restoration. The process began with the DC platter motor, which is typical for these units. After nearly 50 years of use, the motor’s Oilite bearings needed re-lubrication. This involved disassembling the motor, immersing the bearings in oil, and creating a vacuum to help the oil penetrate.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Hood Restoration
item.description: I am currently restoring a Beogram 4002 (5503) and focused on refurbishing its dust cover. As you can see in the first image, the cover had multiple scratches and abrasions common for its age. My first step was to sand the cover using 220-grit sandpaper to smooth out the imperfections. Following this, I used a Micro-Mesh polishing cloth to restore the cover’s clarity. The final result is a clear and revitalized dust cover.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Keypad
item.description: Following the restoration of the Beogram 4000’s arm carriage, attention shifted to the keypadâ€”the turntable’s control center housing the early digital control system. A single screw secures the keypad, allowing access to its internal components. Uniquely, this keypad lacked visible wiring underneath, unlike other 4000 models with wiring behind the latch. Instead, the wiring harness was cleverly routed into the pad from the front, simplifying reassembly. The restoration process began by addressing the fragile light bulbs illuminating the arm position scale and RPM trimmers.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A Very Corroded New Arrival from Sweden
item.description: My initial assessment of the Beogram 4000 from Sweden is a mixed bag. Positively, the aluminum surfaces, platter, arm cover lettering, and panels are in good shape, though a thorough cleaning is needed to determine their true condition. The internal components appear original, and the red position indicator is intact. However, there are significant drawbacks. The black enclosure parts have an unprecedented amount of corrosion, exceeding typical wear and tear. This corrosion is present even on the underside and has also affected the chassis’s leaf springs.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
item.description: My work began on the Beogram 4000 turntable that arrived from Germany. As is my practice, the tracking and arm lowering mechanisms were the first to be refurbished. The arm lowering mechanism, controlled by a solenoid and damper arrangement, is pictured here: After removing components requiring cleaning and lubrication, the area looked like this: Here are the disassembled parts: With cleaning and lubrication complete, reassembly followed. Next, I addressed the seized damper-to-arm linkage, accessible only after detaching the sensor arm.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Intermittent "17" Position Switch Causing Immediate Touchdown After Launch
item.description: I thought I was finished with this Beogram 4000 turntable after refurbishing its dust cover. However, a new problem emerged. After playing a few records, the tonearm would drop next to the platter as soon as I pressed “ON.” Luckily, the stylus wasn’t damaged (thanks to proper arm height adjustment), but I clearly needed to examine the carriage mechanism’s “17” position switch. This particular switch is the most troublesome of the position switches because it’s the only “break switch.

item.title: Beogram 4002: A New Day, a New Hood!
item.description: I recently got a new dust cover for a Beogram turntable from Beoparts-shop in Denmark. These covers are made using the same injection molding process as the originals, so they have a seamless look, unlike older reproduction covers that were made by fusing together laser-cut pieces. The result is a cover that’s indistinguishable from the original. This photo shows the new cover: The hinge for the cover was missing the small plastic pieces that prevent the spring mechanism from rubbing against the hinge’s metal parts.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a New Plexiglass Hood and Aluminum Trim
item.description: The restoration of my Beogram 4000 is nearly complete. The final cosmetic touch was adding a new, reproduction dust cover from Classic Audio in Denmark. They also supplied a matching aluminum trim piece for the back edge. Installing the dust cover was simple. Here’s a look at the process: This image showcases the original hinge being installed with new stainless steel screws: The pre-drilled holes in the new cover aligned perfectly, and the screws went in just like the original.

item.title: Beogram 4000 (type 5215): replacing sensor arm photo cell with modern one
item.description: I recently had two Beogram turntables (a BG4000 and a BG4002) in my workshop with malfunctioning photocells in the detector arm. Usually, these photocells have a long lifespan, but the light bulbs can experience broken wires. While a pre-existing LED replacement for these bulbs exists (see sensor arm light bulb replacement), in this instance, the photocells themselves had broken wires and even a fractured cell, rendering repair impossible. Finding replacements proved futile as well.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoring the Hood
item.description: I finally decided to refurbish the dust cover of the Beogram 4000 turntable from Norway, a task that takes me around 3 hours. I had been putting it off because I was enjoying working on a custom transformer for a Beomaster 4000 receiver. As is common with vintage turntables, the dust cover on this Beogram 4000 was showing its age. It had numerous scratches and blemishes, as you can see here:

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from Massachusetts
item.description: It’s always wonderful to see a returning customer! Earlier this year, I restored a Beogram 4000 for a client in Massachusetts. Now, I’m excited to work on another Beogram 4000 he’s sent my way. It seems one can never have too many Beograms! The Beogram 4000 arrived safely, shipped securely in a Beolover box. It was accompanied by a thoughtful gift for Beolover, for which I am incredibly grateful. This beautiful reissue of “Waltz for Debby” by the Bill Evans Trio, a legendary jazz record, is a 180g pressing.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the Hood
item.description: The final stage of my recent Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration project involved reviving the dust cover. Like many Beograms of its era, the cover required attention, particularly the rubber bumpers which needed replacing. The extent of the damage is evident in this photo: Fortunately, the scratches weren’t severe. A 320-grit sanding step effectively leveled the plexiglass, preparing it for polishing to regain its transparency: After approximately ten stages of polishing, using progressively finer sandpaper and polishing cloths, the cover regained its shine:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjustments, Cleaning the Aluminum Surfaces and a First Spin with Freddie Hubbard!
item.description: Following the installation of a new gold-plated DIN 5 plug, the Beogram 4000 was ready for its initial test. The RPM was fine-tuned using a custom Beolover RPM device, aided by the recently installed precision multi-turn trimmers. It’s important to note that allowing the unit to warm up for approximately 15 minutes before this adjustment is recommended, as the RPM can fluctuate slightly during this period. For fellow enthusiasts, the Beolover RPM device is available upon request via email or the contact form and includes a separate base for convenient setup and occasional RPM checks.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of a Stuck RPM Relay with a Modern Encapsulated SMD Relay
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, the motor wouldn’t switch to 45 RPM. After changing the control panel lights, it became obvious that the 45 RPM button lit up the correct trimmer pot but the motor speed didn’t change. The issue was a faulty relay that was responsible for switching resistor networks within the Wien oscillator’s feedback loop to adjust the resonance frequency. Finding a replacement relay for vintage electronics can be tricky.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Lubricating and Adjusting the Solenoid to Tonearm Linkages
item.description: Following the solenoid replacement and removal of the faulty voltage regulator on my Beogram 4000 restoration project, the arm mechanism remained sluggish. This indicated a need to lubricate the connection between the damper and tonearm lift. Additionally, the tonearm’s horizontal alignment was significantly off. While attempting to adjust this with the set screw on the tonearm counterweight’s connecting arm, I discovered it was glued in place with epoxy, preventing screwdriver access - likely another consequence of a previous repair attempt.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Hood Restoration - Polishing and Exchange of the Hinge
item.description: My recent Beogram 4000 restoration project required a hood restoration. I had two hoods: one had a cracked corner, and the other had a good plexiglass body but a corroded hinge. Corrosion is common on Beogram 4000 hinges. It’s fixable with sanding and repainting, but finding a good hinge is preferable. Luckily, the cracked hood had a usable hinge, so I decided to swap them. Removing the hinge requires care to avoid damaging the aluminum strip on the back of the hood.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Installation of a New All-Metal DIN5 Plug with Gold Plated Contacts
item.description: I believe that any restoration of a Beogram 4002 isn’t truly finished until the old output plugs, which are often corroded, are replaced with modern, all-metal ones featuring gold-plated terminals. High-quality analog signals deserve the best possible connections. Here are some photos documenting the DIN5 plug replacement I completed on a Beogram 4002 (5503) restoration: The original DIN5 plug is shown here: This photo shows the “under the hood” soldering work:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Keyboard Keys - Video About Removal and Installation
item.description: After restoring a Beogram 4000, I shipped it to a customer, but two keypad keys came loose during transport. To secure them, I had used tape and foam, but the shipping stress was too much for the delicate leaf spring mechanism holding the keys. To prevent this from happening again, I created special tools that make it easier to install the keys and shared a video demonstrating their use. These tools, designed to avoid damaging the aluminum, are available to other enthusiasts.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a Brand New Beautiful Solid Oak Plinth! - Very Beolovely!!
item.description: It’s another great day for a Beogram enthusiast like myself! I recently received two new Beogram plinths from Matt Spangler of Vintage HiFi Nut in Oregon. He’s an expert in restoring and replacing vintage HiFi wood cabinets. I had sent him a Beogram 4000 and a Beogram 4002 plinth a while back. Both had been damaged in transit because of inadequate packaging, a frequent problem as people often don’t realize how rough shipping can be.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Hood Restoration - Exchange of Trim, Fixing Cracked Hinges, Spray Painting Corroded Metal Parts and Polishing
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I’m currently working on had a damaged dust cover. It was scratched, the metal hinges were corroded, the plexiglass around the hinges was cracked, and it had the typical early-model plastic trim that imitated aluminum. To start, I removed the plastic trim. It was attached with contact cement, so I warmed the dust cover in the oven at approximately 80 degrees Celsius (wrapped in aluminum foil to prevent hot spots) to soften the adhesive.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Tracking Sensor Incandescent Bulb with a Drop-In SMD LED Assembly and a Peek at the Opto-Resistors
item.description: The tracking sensor bulb in my Beogram 4000 recently burned out. This was the fourth bulb to fail. I decided to use this opportunity to install my new SMD LED replacement assembly. This assembly uses efficient white LEDs at low power for longevity, likely exceeding 50 years. It also reduces the unit’s energy consumption by a few watts, lessening the load on the aging transformer. Details about the assembly and adjustments can be found in this video.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Installation of New Aluminum Pulley for the Carriage Servo
item.description: Recently, I completed the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5501) turntable. The final piece I needed was a new aluminum pulley for the carriage servo. The original pulley was cracked and causing unwanted noise and vibration, particularly during rapid carriage movements like starting and stopping. This was not acceptable for a quality turntable. A standard replacement pulley wasn’t compatible with this early 5501 model. These early models use a unique end groove detection system requiring a pulley with four holes that function as an optical chopper to monitor the carriage speed.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from Australia
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable from Australia recently arrived and I’m excited to share my initial assessment. Despite the packaging using incredibly small packing peanuts (resulting in a big mess!), the turntable arrived in great shape. The attached image showcases the turntable as I unpacked it: This Beogram 4000 has a nice dust cover with minimal scratching, good aluminum trim, and intact plexiglass hinges. It’s definitely worth keeping and polishing. Under the dust cover, things are looking good as well.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cleaning the Switches
item.description: A significant issue with the Beogram 4000 design lies in its numerous exposed mechanical switches. Many usability problems stem from oxidized or bent contact tabs on these switches. Attempts to fix these issues often involve bending the contact tabs, which can worsen the problem. This was true for the Beogram I’m currently restoring. After replacing the solenoid, the right slide transfer button malfunctioned. While replacing the control panel’s light bulbs with SMD LEDs, I also cleaned the switch contacts.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Repair of Cracked Hood Hinge
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable had a broken hood hinge, a common problem caused by the design. The weight of the hood and the type of screws used put too much stress on the plexiglass, leading to cracks. The hinge was broken in one place, and the rest of it was still attached, but cracked. After carefully removing the old glue and aluminum strip, the broken piece was glued back on.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Upgrade of Signal Path with New DIN5 Plug and a Grounding Switch
item.description: The DIN5 plug on the Beogram 4000 being restored was heavily oxidized and needed replacement. A new, fully metal plug with gold-plated terminals was installed. To improve the signal output, a switch was added to connect the signal and system grounds. This feature is beneficial when using a DIN5 to RCA adapter, as RCA cables lack a system ground. Connecting the system ground to the signal ground on the Beogram can reduce humming.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Complete Functional Restoration
item.description: Some time ago, a customer in Texas purchased a Beogram 4000 turntable on eBay from a seller in New York. The turntable was in fair condition, as detailed on the blog (see hyperlink). To address a cracked corner on the dust cover, the decision was made to acquire a second Beogram 4000, allowing the creation of one flawless unit from the two. With the arrival of the second turntable, the restoration began.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of Broken Off MMC Cartridge Mount with 3D Printed Replacement Assembly
item.description: I recently obtained a Beogram 4000 tonearm with a common issue: a broken MMC cartridge mounting tab due to the aging plastic. Fortunately, this tonearm had an older design allowing for easy disassembly. The plastic piece meant to hold the cartridge was broken, leaving only the circuit board behind. The broken piece was glued in, requiring careful heating in boiling water to soften the glue before removal. Thankfully, a crucial part with the grounding tab remained intact and was reusable.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A Fun Evening with a Smoking Solenoid Resistor
item.description: This continues my series “A Fun Evening with…” A Beogram 4000 turntable, which I had previously restored, was returned with a malfunctioning arm lowering mechanism and a burning smell. I removed the turntable from its case and took off the aluminum plates to examine it. When I powered it on, it initially started up as usual, but the arm wouldn’t lower at the record’s starting point. Instead, there was a strong burning smell and a plume of smoke coming from the circuit board with the carriage switches.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A First Look
item.description: This Beogram 4000, recently acquired in Germany, is about to undergo a complete restoration before being sent to its new home in the UK. A preliminary assessment reveals the aluminum surfaces to be in quite good condition. The teak plinth is similarly well-preserved, with notably sharp corners. While the original arm cover shows significant dirt accumulation, thorough cleaning is likely to improve its appearance. Sourcing a replacement would be challenging due to the unique labeling on this model â€“ “tracking weight adjusting” instead of the “tracking force adjustment” found on the 4002.

item.title: Beogram 4000: MMC Cartridge Mount Restoration
item.description: A Beogram 4000 tonearm from Western Australia needed repair because its MMC cartridge mount had broken off, a common issue with these models. Unlike later models with soldered wiring, this older model has a plug-in tonearm, which complicates the mount replacement. The old mount, held by glue, had to be carefully removed. Heating the arm softens the glue, allowing for the broken mount’s removal. This process was used for both the Australian tonearm and another one undergoing restoration.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A First Look at a New Arrival from Berlin
item.description: My first project in Germany this year is a Beogram 4000 turntable. While the packaging from Berlin was good, the dust cover was cracked in one corner, likely due to inadequate protection by the seller. Thankfully, the turntable itself is in decent cosmetic condition. The aluminum surfaces are mostly unscathed, with some minor scratches from the tonearm assembly, probably because the transport lock wasn’t engaged. The wooden base is also in good shape.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Increasing Tonearm Lowering Delay
item.description: After installing a new hood on a Beogram 4000 turntable, the author noticed the tonearm descended too quickly. Adjusting the damper’s screw didn’t solve the problem, as the tonearm still dropped rapidly despite the damper slowing down. Further inspection revealed the damper’s linkage was positioned very close to the damper plunger. This proximity meant the linkage moved immediately when the damper activated, even before the damper could build up enough vacuum to slow the tonearm’s descent effectively.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Exchanging the Electrolytic Capacitors, the RPM Relay, and Adjusting the Motor Signal
item.description: My work on the Beogram 4000 turntable restoration continued with replacing all the electrolytic capacitors on the main board and power supply. I used high-quality, long-lasting Japanese components rated at 105C. Knowing that the RPM relays in these models can fail over time, I decided to swap out the old relay with a new one for improved long-term reliability. My objective is to restore these vintage turntables to like-new condition, both aesthetically and functionally.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the AC Motor Voltage
item.description: During my Beogram 4000 turntable restoration, I observed a noisy motor, especially at 45 RPM. Replacing the electrolytic capacitors helped but didn’t solve the problem completely. To investigate further, I examined the motor voltage and the signal waveform from the Wien bridge oscillator, a clever design that uses an incandescent light bulb as a variable resistor for amplitude control. I measured the AC waveform amplitude at one of the motor leads relative to ground.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of New Reservoir and Motor Phase Capacitors Using a 3D Printed Adapter
item.description: I’m currently restoring a Beogram 4000 and it was time to replace the large capacitors. This is a process I enjoy, made easier with a 3D printed adapter I designed. This adapter allows for the use of smaller, modern capacitors while maintaining a neat and organized appearance. I have a previous post detailing the connections for anyone who might find it helpful, as there are several jumpers that require re-soldering.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Reservoir and Motor Phase Capacitors
item.description: My recent Beogram 4000 restoration involved replacing the motor phase capacitor and reservoir. I used a 3D-printed adapter I designed, which allows for secure mounting of modern, smaller capacitors in the original location using the factory bracket. This post provides a closer look at the replacement process and includes a comprehensive wiring diagram for the capacitors. This can be particularly helpful for those tackling this task for the first time.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjustment of the Tonearm Height and Tracking Force
item.description: I’m currently restoring a Beogram 4000 turntable, and with the major tasks complete, I’ve shifted my focus to the finer points. One detail that caught my eye was the tonearm’s resting position, which was noticeably higher than the sensor arm when lifted. [Image] Although this doesn’t impact sound quality, it was aesthetically displeasing. After consulting the manual, which recommended aligning the tonearm height with the sensor arm, I made the adjustment.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of the Incandescent Bulb in the Sensor Arm with an LED
item.description: To ensure stability after restoring Beograms, I like to test them thoroughly. While playing records on a recently revived Beogram 4000, the sensor arm’s light bulb burned out. This presented a chance to modify my LED assembly design, previously used for the Beogram 4002, to fit the Beogram 4000. The redesigned Kapton flex board can be folded to fit the sensor arm bulb cavity: A 3D-printed wedge, attached to the back, positions the LED for optimal light reflection into the arm’s sensor.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Repair of Misaligned Plinth Corner
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), a previously repaired corner of the plinth required attention. The corners of these plinths commonly separate due to glue deterioration. While it’s usually straightforward to repair them with wood glue, this particular corner hadn’t been aligned properly during a prior attempt. Furthermore, noticeable glue residue on the veneer needed addressing. Fortunately, Mr. Clean Magic Eraser Pads effectively removed the residue without sanding.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoration of the Worn Keypad
item.description: The Beogram 4002 Type 5523 I’m currently working on, like many others, required keypad restoration due to a common issue of a worn-out start key. The keypad’s condition upon arrival is shown in the first image. The second picture showcases the keypad’s appearance after restoration. To avoid damaging the keypad coating through contact with finger oils and friction, we suggest using a soft cloth for operation, regardless of whether it’s restored or original.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Redesigned Drop-In Tracking Sensor Light Bulb Replacement
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, I decided to upgrade the tracking sensor light bulb with a new SMD LED design I had created. My previous design lacked stability with the intensity adjustment trimmer, so I redesigned it to be more secure and visually appealing. The new design incorporates the trimmer directly onto the circuit board and houses it within the light shield. This required modifications to the 3D printed housing to accommodate the trimmer.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Polishing the Hood
item.description: As a final step in restoring a Beogram 4000 turntable, the author polished its dust cover. This is a multi-step process that can take several hours, especially since this cover had significant damage. The author began by protecting the Bang & Olufsen logo with layers of insulation tape to prevent accidental sanding. They then used 220-grit sandpaper to smooth out the deep scratches, leaving a surface that resembled wood. To restore the shine, they progressed through approximately ten grades of sandpaper and micro-mesh polishing cloths, finishing with a polishing liquid.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of a Cracked Hood - Another Process Improvement
item.description: The Beogram 4002 I’m currently working on has a cracked hood around the hinge attachments. The left side was entirely detached, and the right side had a crack extending around one of the holes. The right side had a crack going all the way around one of the attachment holes: To begin, I glued the broken pieces back together using Weld-On #4 acrylic solvent. This low-viscosity solvent is ideal for injecting into cracks, as capillary action draws it in.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of a Cracked Cartridge Mount with a 3D Printed Assembly
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I’m currently repairing has a common issue: a cracked MMC cartridge mount. This piece, made from a more delicate plastic in the 4000 compared to the later 4002 models, tends to deteriorate over time. Here’s a visual representation of the problem: To begin the repair, the tonearm needs to be removed to access the damaged part. After removing the back screw, the tonearm can be gently pulled out:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoring the Slow Slide Transport Function
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, a problem was encountered where the tonearm carriage would continue moving after attempting to move it in reverse. This issue stemmed from a damaged keypad switch, specifically a bent contact terminal that prevented a clean shut-off connection. This damage was likely caused by a previous repair attempt. To address this, the control panel and circuit board were removed to access and extract the switch terminals.

item.title: Beogram 4000: End Groove Detection Issue
item.description: Following the hood polishing, I believed my work on this Beogram 4000 was complete, but I was mistaken. A final functionality test before packing revealed a peculiar issue. When the ON button was pressed without a record on the platter, the carriage would move inward as expected, but then halt abruptly before reaching the end switch (ES). Pressing FF would release it, but the carriage would instantly retract without contacting the ES.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a New Gold Coated DIN5 Plug and a Grounding Switch
item.description: My restoration of the Beogram 4000 is progressing well. I’ve added a grounding switch and a new gold-plated Neutrik DIN5 plug. The switch allows users to choose between the grounding setup of the older 4000/4002 models (separate signal and system grounds) and the later 4004 models (combined grounds). This option helps prevent ground loops and the resulting humming, depending on the amplifier being used. I wrote a detailed post on this topic a while back.

item.title: Beogram 4000: New Arrival from Italy
item.description: I’m thrilled to be working on another Beogram 4000 restoration. The unit arrived from overseas in just three days and was packaged very well, ensuring its safe arrival. The exterior looks good overall. The wood veneer is undamaged and the dust cover can be polished back to its original shine. The aluminum trim on the back of the dust cover needs to be reattached, which should be a simple fix. Inside, the aluminum plates need a thorough cleaning.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Polishing the Hood and a Strange Hinge Pin
item.description: I’m completing the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable by addressing the final detail: polishing the dust cover. This one, like many I’ve encountered, had scratches from improper storage. This particular unit had a non-original hinge pin, longer than the original, causing it to protrude. I shortened it, restoring a flush fit. The aluminum trim on the other side had also detached, which I reattached using double-sided tape for easy future removal.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a Brand New Hood!
item.description: During a recent Beogram 4000 restoration, my customer opted for a brand new reproduction hood from Beoparts-shop in Denmark. These hoods mark a significant advancement in Beogram 400x restoration. Crafted through injection molding, they perfectly mirror the original hoods, eliminating the seams found in laser-cut and fused alternatives. Simply put, these hoods are identical in appearance to the originals. Developed by Beoworld’s Dillen, their availability has greatly benefited Beogram 400x restorations.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of the Reservoir and Motor Capacitors
item.description: Following the restoration of the carriage transport and arm lowering mechanisms, the electrolytic capacitors in the Beogram 4000 restoration project required attention. Replacing the original reservoir and motor capacitors in AC motor Beograms is always satisfying, and the 4000 boasts an impressive collection of large capacitors. The initial step involved removing the outdated capacitors. A quick assessment using a BK LCR tester identified two faulty capacitors. One of the 2200uF capacitors registered a meager 7.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5504): Complete Functional Restoration
item.description: This article details the refurbishment of a Beogram 4002 (5504) turntable. An initial assessment of the unit is documented in a previous post here. The turntable, stripped of its panels and platter, appeared relatively untouched. However, evidence of previous work emerged later. The restoration began with the carriage assembly, which was quite dirty. After disassembling and cleaning the parts, the platter motor and capacitors were removed for thorough cleaning. The motor housing, including the bearings, underwent an oil infusion process under vacuum.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Repair of a Cracked Plexiglass Hood With Laser Cut Patches
item.description: The hinge area is the most delicate part of plexiglass hoods found on Beogram turntables. It’s subject to significant stress when opened and closed, while the presence of screw holes for the metal hinge makes it structurally vulnerable. I recently worked on a Beogram 4000 with a cracked hood and a broken-off piece. Inspired by a previous restoration of a Beogram 3000 hinge, I aimed to create a similar solution for the 4000/4002 models.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5504): A New Arrival from Australia with a Very Creative Way to Send the Cartridge Along!
item.description: The same Australian who owned the Beogram 4000 I recently restored also sent me a Beogram 4002 (a Type 5504) for refurbishment. Like the first turntable, it arrived safely in good condition thanks to its double boxing. This unit came equipped with an MMC20E cartridge, secured in a uniquely inventive manner. Upon inspection at my workbench, I was greeted with this: Removing the styrofoam revealed the following: This novel approach, while unusual, seemed surprisingly effective for transporting a cartridge in the absence of a proper container.

item.title: Beogram 4000: New Aluminum Carriage Pulley
item.description: Following the gold plating of all spring terminals in the switches, this Beogram 4000 received another upgrade: a replacement for the old, unstable plastic carriage pulley, now made from aluminum. The original pulley is shown below: And here it is equipped with one of Nick’s well-crafted aluminum pulleys: Contact me if you need a pulley for your Beogram; I’d be happy to connect you with Nick. These pulleys are compatible with the 4002 and 4004 models as well.

item.title: Beogram 4000: An Unusual Keypad PCB
item.description: This article highlights a unique Beogram 4000 keyboard PCB. Typically, the two bulbs illuminating the position scale are wired in series, using two 12V bulbs connected between the 24V power source and ground. This setup is illustrated in the first image and diagram. Notably, this series configuration results in the bulbs having opposite polarity. This polarity difference is ideal for the author’s polarized LED replacement boards. The second image showcases these boards.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival From New York
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable recently purchased on eBay was shipped using a specialized container to protect it in transit. Thankfully, the seller mostly followed the provided packing guidelines, resulting in no damage during shipping. Upon opening, the turntable was in good condition, with only minor issues. While the blue tape used on the aluminum surfaces didn’t cause any damage to the lettering, there were a few scratches on the platter. These were likely caused by attempts to remove it improperly.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Platter and the Chassis
item.description: Having completed the restoration of the Beogram 4000, I noticed the platter wasn’t sitting correctly within its aluminum panel. It needed adjustments to align it properly. The service manual suggests adjusting the platter in relation to the chassis first, and then aligning the chassis within the enclosure. This ensures the platter sits flush and centered within the panel, achieving that desirable “Beoloving” aesthetic. To illustrate the process, I created two videos.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the AC Motor and Replacement of the Reservoir and Motor Capacitors
item.description: Following the restoration of the Beogram 4000’s printed circuit boards, attention shifted to the capacitors associated with the reservoir and motor, as well as the AC motor itself. The capacitor and motor section appeared as shown before any servicing. Visual inspection revealed leakage from the larger capacitors, indicating a critical need for replacement. The extent of the capacitor bay’s condition was evident upon their removal. The AC motor was extracted for servicing, taking advantage of its disconnected state from the capacitors.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Installation of Upgrades - Internal RIAA Preamp, Commander Remote Control and a New Hood
item.description: Following the functional restoration of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5503) from Oklahoma, the next step was to add the customer’s desired upgrades. These included an internal Beolover RIAA pre-amplifier (designed for AC motor Beogram 4002s), a Beolover Commander remote control system, and a new hood for a pristine appearance. The first upgrade was preparing the keypad for the Commander remote system. AC motor Beograms primarily use directly soldered wiring harnesses, so Commander installation isn’t “plug and play” like the DC motor version.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Exchange of Black Painted Plinth with a Teak Plinth from a Beogram 4002
item.description: I’m working on restoring a Beogram 4000 turntable, and it came with a perplexing modification: a black-painted plinth. While I appreciate the iconic design of the original, I found myself needing to replace the plinth entirely. The photos below illustrate the process: Hereâ€™s the turntable with the black plinth, showing the cracked guidance washers, a common issue Iâ€™ve encountered: I took the plinth off, which requires removing the keypad to access a hidden bolt:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Recapping the PCBs
item.description: During my Beogram 4000 restoration, I replaced all electrolytic capacitors as a preventative measure, opting for durable 105C types from reputable Japanese brands. Tantalum capacitors, particularly in older equipment, can fail dramatically, even catching fire. On the power supply board, I discovered a missing screw and a loose one, potentially creating a dangerous short circuit scenario. Thankfully, no damage was evident. I replaced the tantalum capacitors and secured the board with a new stainless steel M3 screw.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Solenoid and the Switches
item.description: The Beogram 4000 restoration I’m working on requires some final adjustments. A key part of any complete restoration is calibrating the solenoid and its associated switches. This solenoid is critical as it manages the tonearm’s up/down movement and activates three important switches: audio muting, solenoid power control, and carriage transport. The audio muting switches are crucial for silencing the cartridge coils until the stylus makes contact with the record, preventing unwanted noise.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Chassis Springs and the Platter Height
item.description: The Beogram 4000 restoration is progressing into the final cosmetic stage. With the turntable functioning correctly, the focus is now on refining the exterior and replacing minor parts like the plug. Currently, I am fine-tuning the platter height, tilt, and the leaf springs supporting the turntable’s floating chassis. This is a delicate process with many interconnected factors. The sensor arm’s alignment, platter angle, transport lock travel, and belt tension all need to be perfect for the platter to be level, centered, and parallel to the arms, all while ensuring the chassis clears the open locks.

item.title: Beogram 4000: RPM Performance Test
item.description: I recently measured the RPM performance of my restored Beogram 4000 turntable. I was curious to see how the AC motor compared to the DC motors found in other models, like the Beogram 8000/8002 with their computer-controlled linear motors. After running the 4000 for 12 hours using my BeoloverRPM device, the results were interesting. The AC motor demonstrated excellent stability, as evidenced by the graph. However, there was an initial period of drift as both the oscillator and motor warmed up.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a Grounding Switch That Allows to Connect System and Signal Grounds
item.description: During my latest restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, I encountered a loud hum when playing records through my Beomaster 6000’s 4-channel phono input. The issue was resolved by connecting the signal and system grounds. Although the root cause of the hum remains unclear, I decided to install a switch to allow for easy toggling between the original separate grounding configuration and a direct connection between signal and system grounds at the turntable’s output.

item.title: Beogram 4000: First Contact
item.description: It’s a joyous occasion! A Beogram 4000 (5215) turntable has arrived for some care and restoration. Although these models are rare in the US, the opportunity to work on one is the next best thing to owning one, especially considering its fascinating diode-transistor-logic (DTL) control system crafted from early NAND/NOR gates and diode arrays. Upon unboxing and setting it up for testing, it became apparent that while mechanically restored and mostly functional, the cabinet had been painted black - a tragedy for vintage audiophiles.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): A New Arrival From New Jersey
item.description: I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 (Type 5503) turntable from a collector in New Jersey who was downsizing their collection. This particular model will be restored for a customer who specifically requested a Beogram 4002 with an AC motor. The turntable arrived securely packaged and in good cosmetic condition, although the dust cover had numerous scratches. I’m considering polishing the cover or replacing it with a newly available reproduction. Upon removing the cover, I noticed the aluminum surfaces were well-maintained, but the keypad had delaminated.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Restoring the Plexiglass Hood
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5514) I recently restored had a very scratched dust cover. [Image of scratched dust cover] If I can feel the scratches with my fingernail, the first restoration step is sanding with 220 grit sandpaper. This creates a smooth surface for polishing. This is what the surface looks like after sanding: [Image of dust cover after sanding] It looks a bit like wood at this stage. After approximately 10 polishing steps using progressively finer sandpaper and then micro-mesh polishing cloths, the surface is restored:

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Pulley, Hood Bumpers and Shipping Back to Italy
item.description: A Beolover always aims for perfection, and I realized my restoration of the Beogram 4000 wasn’t quite finished. Working on a Beogram 8000 reminded me of the importance of rubber hood bumpers for a smooth, quiet closing action. I discovered these bumpers were missing on the Beogram 4000, leaving only remnants of degraded rubber. To fix this, I carefully removed the old rubber with a small drill bit by hand, avoiding any damage to the plexiglass.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of a Seized Solenoid to Tonearm Linkage
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I got from the UK had a seized linkage connecting the solenoid mechanism and tonearm. To lubricate this linkage, I had to disassemble the sensor arm assembly and remove it. Further inspection showed that the linkage’s rotating pin was stuck and had detached from its press-fit socket within the sensor arm base. I’ve created a video illustrating the problem and the repair process:

item.title: Beogram 4000 Arrives! First Impressions!
item.description: I was lucky enough to get a Beogram 4000 turntable today! It needs a little work, but it came with a perfect MMC20EN cartridge â€“ I’m listening to Miles Davis on it right now and it sounds incredible! The outside and dust cover are in great shape, and the platter looks really good too. Here are my initial thoughts: The control panel is nice (ignore the Sharpie marks under the position indicator for now…):

item.title: Beogram 4000: Reservoir and Motor Phase Capacitors Replacement
item.description: I recently provided a customer with replacement capacitors for his Beogram 4000 turntable, along with a 3D-printed adapter I designed. He had been experiencing problems with the motor, as it was only displaying half waveforms. This suggested an issue with either the phase capacitor or the power supply reservoir capacitors. After installing the new components, the problem was completely resolved. You can find more details about this process in my original post here: link to my original post about this procedure.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Exchanging the Plinth Panels
item.description: The Beogram 4000 being restored arrived with a damaged plinth corner. As replacements are scarce, panels from a 4002 or 4004 model are often substituted, necessitating a swap of the metal fixtures due to variations in keypad design. The restoration begins by detaching the plinth from the metal casing. Heating the plinth in a warm oven (around 80Â°C) for 30-45 minutes softens the adhesive, allowing for the removal of the metal fixtures with a spatula.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A Fun Time with a Suddenly Activating Solenoid, an Anemic Carriage Motor, and an AC Motor Driver with a Weak Driver Amplitude
item.description: I’m repairing a Beogram 4000 turntable and encountered some unusual problems. After rebuilding the boards and motors, I noticed the carriage moved slowly. The 24V rail was only reading 21V, significantly lower than the expected 23.8V. Then, the arm lowering solenoid began activating erratically when the carriage was touched. It turned out the chassis had a 30V potential relative to the system ground, a dangerous situation. I found a short circuit between the 24V reservoir capacitor and ground.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival From Michigan - A First Look
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable arrived from Michigan for restoration, carefully packaged according to instructions. The aluminum surfaces are in good condition, with one minor dent on the platter’s surrounding plate. The platter itself, keypads, and small aluminum plate are also in good shape. However, one corner of the plinth is damaged. Fortunately, replacement plinth panels were included, which will be installed. The hood has noticeable scratches, primarily on the surface, and should polish well.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Hood Restoration
item.description: The final step in restoring my Beogram 4000 involved replacing the damaged dust cover with one from a donor unit. While the replacement had some typical scratches, it was in good condition overall. I began by sanding the surface with 320 grit sandpaper to remove the scratches. The next step was to polish it back to its original shine and clarity. Here’s the dust cover after polishing with 800 grit:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Replacement of Corroded RCA Plugs
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5523) currently under restoration was equipped with RCA plugs and a grounding wire instead of the typical DIN 5 connector. The plugs and grounding terminal were noticeably dirty and corroded. The RCA plugs were switched out for all-metal gold-plated ones, and a new grounding terminal was installed. These compact RCA plugs lack color coding, so 3D-printed inserts were created. These inserts enclose the back of the plugs and provide a visual distinction between the left and right channels.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Installation of a Brand New Hood and Aluminum Trim
item.description: I recently obtained a Beogram 4002 hood hinge from Florida to use in the installation of a new hood. The first photo shows its condition upon arrival. A closer look revealed the problem: The mounting holes on the hood had developed a fracture. This is a common issue caused by the original design choices made by B&O. The use of flat head bolts placed lateral stress on the plexiglass, leading to cracks and eventual breakage.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Light Bulbs in the Control Panel and Gold Plating of the Keypad Contact Terminals
item.description: The next stage of restoring my Beogram 4000 involved working on the control panel. Typically, I swap out the old incandescent bulbs for LEDs and clean the keypad’s contacts. This particular unit had three out of four bulbs burnt out, highlighting the wisdom of switching to LEDs for their superior lifespan. I had recently designed SMD LED boards to replace the position scale illumination bulbs (the top two) and had them professionally manufactured.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): When Disaster Strikes! - Replacement of the Solenoid Switch and Restoration of a Melted Solenoid
item.description: It seems my Beogram 4002 customer in Arizona is having arm lowering issues again, just a short time after my last repair in December 2022. Upon opening the unit, I discovered the solenoid had completely melted down due to a faulty arm extension I had previously installed. This prevented the solenoid switch from deactivating, leading to overheating and ultimately, failure. To fix this, I crafted a new solenoid coil and replaced the melted one.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Polishing of the In- and Outside of the Hood
item.description: After installing a new remote control and internal pre-amplifier, the final touch on this Beogram 4002 (5523) was polishing its dust cover. While the outside showed typical scratches, the inside had an unusually large scratch as well. Polishing the inside is more challenging because the polishing tool can hit the corners. However, because this scratch was situated away from the edges, it could be addressed. The technique involved gradually widening the polished area with each step.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Light Bulbs in the Control Panel with LEDs
item.description: Following the replacement of the reservoir and motor capacitors in the Beogram 4000, I focused on upgrading the control panel’s light bulbs. LEDs offer greater long-term stability and are generally preferable replacements for incandescent bulbs, except in cases where the original circuitry or aesthetics demand otherwise. Given that the control panel’s lighting is internal and not directly visible, LEDs are a suitable replacement. In this instance, one of the bulbs illuminating the position scale had failed, causing the entire scale to go dark due to the series arrangement of the two bulbs.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New DIN 5 Plug and Installation of a Grounding Switch
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I’m currently restoring had a severely corroded and improperly installed DIN 5 plug, clearly not the original. The attached photos illustrate its poor condition. One of the pictures highlights a loose black wire, potentially a makeshift attempt to address humming issues (unsurprising given the plug’s installation). Adding to the problem, a poorly executed soldering job had left one of the signal leads disconnected. I removed the old plug and prepared the wires for a new one, as shown in the photo.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cleaning the Carriage Position Switches and Fixing a Bent Output Switch Contact Tab
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000, a process known as “switch day” involves cleaning the contacts of the many open switches. While some recommend desoldering the switches for thorough cleaning, it’s generally sufficient to clean the contact areas directly. This minimizes the risk of damaging the delicate contact tabs. Effective switch functionality hinges on clean contact points, not the overall appearance of the switch. The contact tabs should be straight and have adequate spring to ensure proper contact.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Polishing the Hood
item.description: The final touch in restoring a Beogram turntable is typically polishing its plexiglass cover. This particular Beogram 4002 had noticeable scratches on its cover, including a branded logo above the platter’s center. Deep scratches that can be felt by hand require an initial sanding with 220-grit sandpaper to level the surface, creating a temporarily rough appearance. If the scratches are less pronounced, starting with 320 or 400-grit sandpaper might suffice.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Light Bulb of the Tracking Sensor with a Drop-In LED Assembly
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 400x turntable, it’s common to replace the tracking sensor’s incandescent bulb with a more durable LED assembly. A drop-in replacement for the Beogram 4002 and 4004 models has been created and documented, while the Beogram 4000 version incorporates a Bang & Olufsen-specified intensity trimmer for fine-tuning the tracking feedback system’s sensitivity. It’s crucial to recalibrate the tracking sensor’s position after any light source replacement to maintain accurate tracking sensitivity.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Keypad Light Bulbs with LEDs
item.description: My Beogram 4000 restoration continued with replacing the control panel’s light bulbs with LEDs. This enhances the unit’s lifespan and prevents issues that incandescent bulbs, susceptible to vibration, can experience during shipping. The top two bulbs illuminate the Beogram’s unique position indicator, while the vertical bulbs light the RPM trimmers. I recently designed SMD LED-based PCB replacements for the position indicator bulbs (available via email). Standard red LEDs with current-limiting resistors can replace the RPM trimmer bulbs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of New DIN5 Plug with Gold Plated Pins
item.description: A gold-plated plug is the finishing touch for a fully restored signal path. Here’s the process on a Beogram 4002(5513) I’m currently working on: Above is the original plug in rough shape due to oxidation. The new Rean plug offers a neat and tidy internal layout. Placing the metal enclosure back results in an even more visually appealing look. That’s the Beolove!

item.title: Beogram 4002: Plexiglass Hood Restoration
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5523) I recently refurbished had a very scratched lid. Fortunately, the hinges were undamaged, and the inside of the lid was in good condition, with only a few minor cleaning marks. This made it worthwhile to try to restore the lid to an acceptable condition. The photo below shows the condition of the lid when I received the Beogram: Because some scratches were deep enough to feel with a fingernail, I began by using 400-grit sandpaper to smooth the surface:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of an 'Old Style' MMC Cartridge Mount with a New 3D Printed Assembly
item.description: The Beogram 4000 restoration involved addressing a frequent problem: a broken MMC cartridge mount. This issue arises because the plastic used in older models becomes brittle over time. Thankfully, later models like the Beogram 4002 and 4004 utilized a more durable plastic, reducing this issue. To begin the repair, the tonearm was removed to allow access to the cartridge mount assembly. Unlike later models where the mount is glued, this older version is bolted to the arm’s aluminum frame.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Glueing a Delaminated Platter Back Together and Installation of New Cabined Guidance Washers
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I’m currently working on was unfortunately damaged during shipping due to inadequate packaging by the seller. Because the platter wasn’t secured, it moved around and ultimately split into two pieces. The images show the separated top and bottom sections of the platter. Examining the platter’s interior reveals interesting details about its construction. The heavier bottom section of each platter was individually balanced, much like car tires. This involved drilling away small amounts of material from the heavier side, as evidenced by the red pen marks near the drill holes.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration and Adjustment of AC Platter Motor
item.description: After restoring the electronics of a Beogram 4000 turntable, attention turned to the AC platter motor. This model features an older pulley design without built-in belt guards, relying instead on separate guards added to the motor mounting posts. These added guards are not essential, as the pulley’s shape effectively secures the belt. Motor tilt allows for adjustments to the belt’s vertical positioning. Like the DC motors in later Beogram models, the AC motors can also suffer from dried-out bearings.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Complete Restoration and a Test Spin with Oscar Peterson
item.description: I recently obtained a Beogram 4000 turntable from Sweden in very corroded condition. To address the extensive corrosion, I chose to use another 4000 unit as a donor for parts. The donor unit, while missing some components, was free of corrosion. My restoration process started with the carriage. I disassembled and cleaned the arm lowering system, damper, carriage rods, and spindle in an ultrasonic bath. Additionally, the sensor arm assembly was removed to lubricate the damper-to-arm linkage pivot point.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Zero Force Balancing and Tracking Force Calibration
item.description: The Beogram 4000 I’m currently restoring is almost ready for its initial test run. It’s time to fine-tune the zero force balance and set the appropriate tracking force. I documented this process in a video on my YouTube channel, featuring a Beogram 4002. You can find the video and my entire Beogram 4000 playlist through the provided links. Let me share some observations from this specific Beogram 4000 restoration. The first stage involves achieving zero force balance.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the PCBs - New Capacitors, RPM Trimmers and RPM Relay
item.description: Following the replacement of the motor and reservoir capacitors in the Beogram 4000 restoration, the next step involved rebuilding the PCBs. This typically involves replacing all electrolytic capacitors, the RPM trimmers, and the RPM relay. The main PCB, which is difficult to remove due to its hardwiring, was ‘flipped’ for component replacement. After replacing the components, the rebuilt board was ready for installation. A new relay was used, as the original Siemens relays often experience oxidation, hindering proper RPM switching.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of Incandescent Light Bulbs in Control Panel with LEDs
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, all four incandescent bulbs in the control panel were found to be non-functional. This highlighted the fragility of these bulbs and emphasized the need for a more durable solution. To address this, the original bulbs were replaced with custom-designed LED replacements. Specifically, the two position indicator bulbs were replaced with surface-mounted LED (SMD LED) units. The two bulbs responsible for illuminating the RPM trimmers were replaced with high-intensity red LEDs.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Keypad Cluster
item.description: Following the repair of the Beogram 4000’s electrolytic capacitors and AC motor, the focus shifted to restoring the keypad cluster. The circuitry underneath the keypad forms the Beogram’s control system, a pioneering digital system utilizing TTL logic chips. This system relies heavily on inputs from numerous mechanical switches within the turntable to make decisions. The keypad itself houses eight of these switches, allowing user interaction. The keypad was held by a single screw, which was missing, hinting at previous tampering.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the AC Motor Voltage and Measuring the Voltage Differences Between the Phases
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, the AC motor requires precise adjustment. The service manual recommends setting the main phase voltage to 6V (RMS) and the frequency to 42.3 Hz for 33 RPM using an oscilloscope. To observe both motor phases, connect the oscilloscope probes across the phase capacitor. Begin the adjustment by setting the 33 RPM trimmer on the control panel to its neutral position. This allows for fine-tuning the RPM offset potentiometer on the main PCB to achieve the target 42.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Full Functional Restoration and a Test Spin with the Bill Evans Trio
item.description: This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable from a Massachusetts customer. The initial evaluation can be found here. The restoration began by addressing the carriage system. This involved cleaning hardened lubricants from various parts like the arm lowering mechanism, rods, spindle, linkages, and damper, and applying modern synthetic lubricants. A key aspect of the Beogram 4000 is its solenoid-activated switches, which frequently experience oxidation and require attention. The contact terminals were removed and re-plated with nickel and gold-cobalt alloy for optimal performance and corrosion resistance.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Tracking Force and Replacing the Strange Original Front Center Cabinet Guiding Washer
item.description: My Beogram 4000 restoration is complete, and it’s playing beautifully. As I write this, I’m enjoying “Song for My Father” by Horace Silver on a reissue, as original pressings are unfortunately outside my budget these days. One of the final tasks was refining the Beogram’s mechanics. I calibrated the tonearm weight and limits and replaced the guiding washer, which ensures the plinth moves smoothly. The original washer, pictured below, has a design flaw that was later corrected in the Beogram 400x series.
